title: 103_hr2198
content: The "Campaign Cost Reduction and Reform Act of 1993" defines a qualifying House of Representatives candidate and makes amendments to the definition of contribution relating to valuation formula and encouragement contributions. Section 301(8)(A) of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to include new clauses regarding the determination of value for contributions, gifts, subscriptions, loans, advances, or deposits of money. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to include new clauses related to contributions made to encourage individuals to become candidates. Amendments are made to the definition of expenditure related to valuation formula and encouragement expenditures. Amendments to Section 301(9)(A) of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 include changes to the valuation formula for determining the value of purchases, payments, distributions, loans, advances, deposits, or gifts of money or anything of value. Amendments to Section 301(9)(A) of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 now include provisions regarding contributions made to encourage individuals to become candidates. SEC. 5. REGISTRATION AS QUALIFYING HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES CANDIDATE. Section 303(b) of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to include a declaration of intention for a candidate running for the office of Representative in Congress to comply voluntarily with contribution and expenditure limitations. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to allow political committees to amend their statement of organization to include a declaration of intention, which cannot be revoked once included. SEC. 6. AMENDMENT TO DEFINITION OF INDEPENDENT EXPENDITURE. Section 301(17) of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to clarify that an expenditure is not considered an independent expenditure if there is any coordination with the candidate or their campaign, or if the person making the expenditure is authorized by the candidate or receives compensation from them. The amendment clarifies that an expenditure is not an independent expenditure if there is coordination with the candidate or their campaign, or if the person making the expenditure is authorized by the candidate. SEC. 7 and SEC. 8 of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 impose limitations on expenditures by qualifying House of Representatives candidates. Candidates are restricted from using personal funds exceeding $75,000 for an election and from making total expenditures over $600,000 in an election cycle. Section 315 of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 has been further amended to impose limitations on House of Representatives candidates. They are restricted from accepting certain amounts of contributions from individuals, political committees, and party committees. Additionally, there are restrictions on independent expenditures advocating for or against a candidate. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 has been amended to limit contributions to House of Representatives candidates. Individuals are restricted from donating more than $2,000 in an election cycle. Those who exceed the limit by 5% or less must pay the excess amount to the Commission. Any person who exceeds the contribution limit by 5% or less must pay the excess amount to the Commission. If the excess is more than 5% but not more than 10%, the penalty is three times the excess amount. Exceeding the limit by more than 10% incurs a penalty of three times the excess amount plus a civil penalty determined by the Commission. SEC. 9. AMENDMENTS TO THE INTERNAL REVENUE CODE OF 1986 RELATING TO THE CREDIT FOR CONTRIBUTIONS TO CERTAIN QUALIFYING HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES CANDIDATES. This section introduces a new rule regarding contributions to qualifying House of Representatives candidates under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The section introduces a new rule allowing individuals to claim a tax credit for contributions to qualifying House of Representatives candidates in their congressional district, with a maximum credit of $100 ($200 for joint returns). Contributions must be verified as prescribed by the Secretary. The section defines "contribution" and "qualifying House of Representatives candidate" as per the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971. Conforming amendments disallow estates or trusts from claiming a tax credit for political contributions. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 1993. The amendments in this Act apply to elections for Federal office starting with the general election of November 8, 1994.
